internal_category.title: Section: 16.01 CURVE FITTING WITH SINUSOIDAL FUNCTIONS
Subtopic: CURVE FITTING WITH SINUSOIDAL FUNCTIONS

sectionBreak.stem:
The pH in a reactor varies sinusoidally over the course of a day as given by the following equation.

 

%media:formula12.mml%     _____ (1)

 

The pH data against the time (hr) is given below.

 

Time, hr 0 2 4 5 7 9 12 15 20 22 24
pH 7.6 7.2 7 6.5 7.5 7.2 8.9 9.1 8.9 7.9 7

internal_category.title: Section: 16.01 CURVE FITTING WITH SINUSOIDAL FUNCTIONS
Subtopic: CURVE FITTING WITH SINUSOIDAL FUNCTIONS

property.name: commonFeedback
property.value:
The angular frequency can be computed as %media:formula93.mml%. The various summations required for the normal equations can be set up as

 

t y cos(ω0t) sin(ω0t) sin(ω0t)cos(ω0t) cos2(ω0t) sin2(ω0t) ycos(ω0t) ysin(ω0t)
0 7.6 1.00000 0.00000 0.00000 1.00000 0.00000 7.60000 0.00000
2 7.2 0.86603 0.50000 0.43301 0.75000 0.25000 6.23538 3.60000
4 7 0.50000 0.86603 0.43301 0.25000 0.75000 3.50000 6.06218
5 6.5 0.25882 0.96593 0.25000 0.06699 0.93301 1.68232 6.27852
7 7.5 –0.25882 0.96593 –0.25000 0.06699 0.93301 –1.94114 7.24444
9 7.2 –0.70711 0.70711 –0.50000 0.50000 0.50000 –5.09117 5.09117
12 8.9 –1.00000 0.00000 0.00000 1.00000 0.00000 –8.90000 0.00000
15 9.1 –0.70711 –0.70711 0.50000 0.50000 0.50000 –6.43467 –6.43467
20 8.9 0.50000 –0.86603 –0.43301 0.25000 0.75000 4.45000 –7.70763
22 7.9 0.86603 –0.50000 –0.43301 0.75000 0.25000 6.84160 –3.95000
24 7 1.00000 0.00000 0.00000 1.00000 0.00000 7.00000 0.00000
Sum→ 84.8 2.31784 1.93185 0.00000 6.13397 4.86603 14.94232 10.18401

 

The normal equations can be assembled as follows:

 

%media:formula94.mml%

 

This system can be solved for A0 = 8.0270, A1 = – 0.59717, and B1 = –1.09392. Therefore, the best-fit sinusoid is as follows:

 

%media:formula107.mml%

 

The result can also be expressed in the alternate form of equation given below by computing the amplitude (C1), the phase shift (θ), and using  the value of A0 = 8.0270 computed above.

 

%media:formula108.mml%

 

The amplitude and the phase shift can be calculated as follows:

 

%media:formula109.mml%

 

%media:formula110.mml%

 

Therefore, the fit can also be expressed as follows:

 

%media:formula106.mml%

internal_category.title: Section: 16.01 CURVE FITTING WITH SINUSOIDAL FUNCTIONS
Subtopic: CURVE FITTING WITH SINUSOIDAL FUNCTIONS
ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value:
The solution is as follows.

 

Mean 8.0270
Amplitude 1.2463
Time of maximum pH 16.0913

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: What is the angular frequency, ω0, for a period of 24 hr?

worksheet.stem:
Use the least-squares fit you obtained from the previous question of the same section to determine the mean, amplitude, and time of maximum pH. Note that the period is 24 hr. (Round the final answers to four decimal places.)

 

The solutions are as follows:

 

Mean __m__
Amplitude __a__
Time of maximum pH __t__ hrs
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The least-squares fit obtained for the given equation is as follows:

 

%media:formula111.mml%

 

Consequently, the mean is 8.0270 and the amplitude is 1.2463. To determine the time of the maximum, inspection of the figure below indicates that a positive phase shift represents the time prior to midnight that the peak occurs.

 

%media:p-16-03.jpg%

 

Therefore, the time of the maximum can be computed as follows:

 

tmax = 24 – 7.0987 = 16.0913 hrs

 

This is equal to about 16:05:29 or 4:05:29 PM. The data and the model can be plotted as follows:

 

%media:p-16-03-a.jpg%

 

The same calculation can be implemented with MATLAB. The coefficients can also be determined with the following script:

 

>> clear,clc,clf,format compact
>> w0 = 2*pi/24;
>> t = [0 2 4 5 7 9 12 15 20 22 24]';
>> pH = [7.6 7.2 7 6.5 7.5 7.2 8.9 9.1 8.9 7.9 7]';
>> Z = [ones(size(t)) cos(w0*t) sin(w0*t)];
>> a = (Z'*Z)\(Z'*pH)
>> Sr = sum((pH - Z*a).^2);
>> syx = sqrt(Sr/(length(t)-length(a)))
>> tp = [0:24]; pHp = a(1)+a(2)*cos(w0*tp)+a(3)*sin(w0*tp);
>> plot(t,pH,'o',tp,pHp)
>> title('Time vs. pH'),xlabel('Time (hours)'),ylabel('pH')
>> mean=a(1),theta = atan2(-a(3),a(2))*24/(2*pi)
>> Amplitude = sqrt(a(2)^2+a(3)^2)
>> time_Max_pH = 24-theta

 

Output:

 

a =
    8.0270
   -0.5972
   -1.0939


syx =
    0.3447


mean =
    8.0270


theta =
    7.9087


Amplitude =
    1.2463


time_Max_pH =
   16.0913

 

%media:p-16-03-b.jpg%

internal_category.title: Section: 16.01 CURVE FITTING WITH SINUSOIDAL FUNCTIONS
Subtopic: CURVE FITTING WITH SINUSOIDAL FUNCTIONS
ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value: The radiation in mid-August is R = 299.1698 W/m2.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: What are the formulas to determine the coefficients when the data are equispaced?

worksheet.stem:
The solar radiation for Tucson, Arizona, has been tabulated as follows:

 

Time, mo J F M A M J J A S O N D
Radiation, W/m2 144 188 245 311 351 359 308 287 260 211 159 131

 

Assuming each month is 30 days long, fit a sinusoid to these data. Use the resulting equation to predict the radiation in mid-August. (Round the final answer to four decimal places.)

 

The radiation in mid-August is R = __r__ W/m2.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The angular frequency can be computed as %media:formula112.mml%. Because the data are equispaced, the coefficients can be determined with the following equations:

 

%media:formula5.mml%

 

%media:formula6.mml%

 

%media:formula7.mml%

 

The various summations required to set up the model can be determined as follows:

 

t Radiation cos(ω0t) sin(ω0t) ycos(ω0t) ysin(ω0t)
15 144 0.96593 0.25882 139.093 37.270
45 188 0.70711 0.70711 132.936 132.936
75 245 0.25882 0.96593 63.411 236.652
105 311 –0.25882 0.96593 –80.493 300.403
135 351 –0.70711 0.70711 –248.194 248.194
165 359 –0.96593 0.25882 –346.767 92.916
195 308 –0.96593 –0.25882 –297.505 –79.716
225 287 –0.70711 –0.70711 –202.940 –202.940
255 260 –0.25882 –0.96593 –67.293 –251.141
285 211 0.25882 –0.96593 54.611 –203.810
315 159 0.70711 –0.70711 112.430 –112.430
345 131 0.96593 –0.25882 126.536 –33.905
Sum→ 2954 - - –614.175 164.429

 

The coefficients can be determined as follows:

 

%media:formula8.mml%

 

%media:formula9.mml%

 

%media:formula10.mml%

 

Therefore, the best-fit sinusoid is


R = 246.1667 – 102.363 cos(0.017453t) + 27.4048 sin(0.017453t)


The data and the model can be plotted as

 

%media:p-16-04.jpg%

 

The value for mid-August can be computed as

 

R = 246.1667 – 102.363 cos(0.017453(225)) + 27.4048 sin(0.017453(225)) = 299.1698

 

The same calculation can be implemented with MATLAB. The coefficients can be determined with the following script.

 

>> clear,clc,clf
>> w0=2*pi/360;
>> t=[15 45 75 105 135 165 195 225 255 285 315 345]';
>> R=[144 188 245 311 351 359 308 287 260 211 159 131]';
>> Z=[ones(size(t)) cos(w0*t) sin(w0*t)];
>> a=(Z'*Z)\(Z'*R)
>> theta = atan2(-a(3),a(2))*360/(2*pi)
>> Amplitude = sqrt(a(2)^2+a(3)^2)
>> RadAug = a(1)+a(2)*cos(w0*225)+a(3)*sin(w0*225)
>> tp=[0:360];
>> Rp=a(1)+a(2)*cos(w0*tp)+a(3)*sin(w0*tp);
>> plot(t,R,'o',tp,Rp)

 

Output

 

a =
  246.1667
 -102.3625
   27.4048

theta =
 -165.0121

Amplitude =
  105.9675

RadAug =
  299.1698

 

%media:p-16-04-a.jpg%

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

sectionBreak.stem:
In electric circuits, it is common to see current behavior in the form of a square wave as shown in the figure below.

 

%media:p-16-06.jpg%

 

Solving for the Fourier series from

 

%media:formula16.mml%

 

the Fourier series can be represented as

 

%media:formula17.mml%

internal_category.title: ABET Outcomes: (a) an ability to apply knowledge of mathematics, science, and engineering

property.name: problemSolution
property.value:
The MATLAB function can be written as follows:

 

function [t,f] = FourierSquare(A0,T,n)
t=[0:T/256:4*T];
nn=length(t);
f=zeros(n,nn);
s=zeros(nn);
for ii = 1:n
    for j = 1:nn
        f(ii,j)=f(ii,j)+4*A0/(2*ii-1)/pi*sin(2*pi*(2*ii-1)*t(j));
        s(j)=s(j)+f(ii,j);
    end
end
hold on
for ii=1:n
    plot(t,f(ii,:),'r:')
end
plot(t,s,'k-','linewidth',2)
hold off
end

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: How can the terms of the Fourier series be added recursively using MATLAB?

worksheet.stem:
Click and drag to create a MATLAB function to generate a plot of the first n terms of the Fourier series individually, as well as the sum of these terms. The function must plot the curves from t = 0 to 4T. Use thin dotted red lines for the individual terms and a bold black solid line for the summation (i.e., 'k-','linewidth',2). The function’s first line should be as follows:

 

function [t,f] = FourierSquare(A0,T,n)

 

__a__
